I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  evidence-based 
solutions for the development of an elderly health services management system in Yunnan 
Province, People’s Republic of China (PRC). The TA will (i) provide options for strengthening 
integration of health services in the elderly care system, and (ii) provide an operational framework 
for effective elderly health care systems in Yunnan Province.1 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 Operational 
Plan for Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities, and emphasizes addressing 
the health care needs of the aging population.2 The TA is in line with the Government of the PRC’s 
national health priority described in the Healthy China 2030 plan and the Thirteenth Five-Year 
Plan, 2016–2020, which advocates the need to support elderly care.3 The TA is included in the 
list of projects agreed between ADB and the Government of the PRC on 22 January 2020.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  A longer life expectancy is an indicator of collective advances in economic, social, and 
health development. In the PRC, most people can expect to live to 65 years and older. In 2018, 
the PRC had the world’s largest population of elderly people aged 65 years and above, totaling 
167 million. The PRC’s aging rate—elderly people aged 65 years and above as a proportion of 
the total population—rose from 7% in 2000 to 12% in 2018, and is expected to reach 14% in 2025, 
and  21%  in  2035.5 This  demographic  transition  to  an  older  population  has  fundamental 
implications for all aspects of society, including family structure, long-term care (LTC), social 
protection, and health. Longevity is contingent on continued good health and quality of life, but 
studies show that aging involves various underlying physiological changes; higher risk of chronic 
and noncommunicable diseases, including heart disease, stroke, respiratory disorders, cancer, 
and dementia; as well as major burdens of disability arising from age-related losses in hearing, 
sight, and movement.6 With life expectancy increasing in the PRC at the rate of about 3 years per 
decade (from 71.4 in 2000 to 77.0 in 2018), older people may spend an average of over 8 years 
living with one or several diseases. 
 
4.  Aging is marked by multidimensional issues resulting from health needs that tend to 
become  more  chronic  and  complex.  Multimorbidity—characterized  by  two  or  more  chronic 
medical conditions of long duration—is becoming the norm as life expectancy increases, and can 
result in health conditions in older age that are not captured by traditional disease classifications. 
A 2018 study found that up to 75% of elderly people have at least one chronic disease, and more 
than 40 million are partially or totally disabled.7 Yunnan Province had an estimated 5.7 million 
older people (aged 65 or above) in 2014, accounting for 11.9% of its total population. This number 
 
1  Elderly care encompasses a wide range of services including assisted living, adult day care, long-term care, nursing 
homes, home care, and social protection. Elderly health care pertains to care for the elderly in a health care setting. 
2  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 1: Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities, 
2019–2024. Manila.  
3  Government of the PRC, National Health Commission. 2019. Healthy China Action Plan (2019–2030): Campaign to 
Prevent Disease and Promote Health. Beijing; and Government of the PRC, State Council. 2015. National Economy 
and Social Development Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, 2016–2020. Beijing. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 20 October 2020. 
5  United Nations Development Programme. 2016. Asia-Pacific Human Development Report—Shaping the Future: 
How Changing Demographics Can Power Human Development. New York. 
6  World Health Organization. 2015. World Report on Ageing and Health. Geneva. 
7  Xinhua News. 2019. China Releases Guideline to Improve Elderly Care (accessed 14 September 2020).

2 
will grow to 12.4% of the total provincial population in 2020.8 Multiple morbidities increase the 
costs, duration, and complexity of medical care, and require a health care system equipped to 
manage the key health issues of older age.  
 
5.  It is critical to understand the variations in health care needs and conditions of the elderly 
population across the province to enable an appropriate approach to health care. A study 
suggested  that  elderly  members  of  ethnic  minority  groups  have  higher  rates  of  chronic 
noncommunicable  diseases than do  non-ethnic  minorities,  as  well  as greater  difficulties  in 
accessing health care.9 An assessment of the health care services available to the elderly 
population in Yunnan must be based on an understanding of the health profile, health care needs, 
and practices of the elderly from the 26 ethnic groups in the province. 
 
6.  The provincial health care system in Yunnan Province needs to adopt a more focused 
approach in order to improve quality and access to appropriate health services for older persons 
with long-term care needs. At present, the health care system is organized to address individual 
acute health conditions rather than chronic conditions of old age, and is not prepared to deliver 
health care for older people that is integrated with local providers and across the continuum of 
care settings (i.e., home, community, and institutional settings). Alignment of long-term health 
care needs with the LTC system in Yunnan will be crucial to maintaining activities of daily living  
and enabling integrated care—which includes disease prevention, health promotion, rehabilitative 
and palliative care, and health-assistive technologies—that is centered on the elderly. For-profit 
elderly health care providers account for a significant proportion of elderly care services, but are 
not well integrated into the health care system. There are also lingering concerns with respect to 
the capacity of caregivers, the efficiency of health care resource allocation, and the effective 
provision and utilization of services, which are important challenges for provincial authorities and 
policymakers. 
 
7.  The PRC Government, partially in response to population aging, has made health a 
national priority as described in the Healthy China 2030 plan, with a central objective of fostering 
health for citizens of all ages (footnote 3). The Fourteenth Five-Year Plan, 2021–2025 will 
increase the focus on elderly health care services, and provide an impetus for the enhancement 
of elderly health services and appropriate alignment of long-term health and LTC systems to 
better serve the older population of Yunnan Province. To be effective, this will require  expanding 
research on aging and allocating more funding for basic health and geriatric care services for the 
older population. Implementing comprehensive research structured for Yunnan Province will 
enable more accurate identification of the unique characteristics of the elderly (including ethnic 
minorities), and their health care needs. This will inform the development of elderly health 
programs focused on preventing chronic diseases, enabling the elderly to overcome chronic pain 
and difficulties while performing daily activities, and establishing a coordinated mechanism for 
LTC. Additionally, policy reforms are a prerequisite to implementing integrated health care 
responses to the aging population; fundamental to the success of these responses are continued 
government commitment, legislation, regulations, and plans for transforming systems for long-
term health care services and LTC provision. 
 
 
 
8  L. Ran et al. 2019. Comparison of Health-Related Quality of Life Between the Han and Yi Ethnicity Elderly in the Yi 
Autonomous Areas of Yunnan Province. BioMed Central Geriatrics. 19 (326). 
9  X. Li et al. 2020. Association of Socioeconomic and Lifestyle Factors with Chronic Non-communicable Diseases and 
Multimorbidity among the Elderly in Rural Southwest China. Journal of Public Health. 42 (2): 239–246.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: access to adequate elderly care services 
improved.10 The TA will have the following outcome: elderly health service management system 
strengthened.11  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Elderly health care services assessed. This output will facilitate contextual 
analysis of the elderly population, including ethnic minorities, to enable formulation of policy 
recommendations  and operational  strategies  for  advancing  elderly  health  services  that  are 
appropriate for the province’s elderly population. The first stage involves (i) a desk review of 
elderly health care policies, regulations, and strategies in Yunnan Province regarding health, 
function, and quality of life of the elderly population, and an analysis of the national and provincial 
policy environment, including elderly health care service standards and human resource plans for 
both for-profit and non-profit services; (ii) key informant interviews with government officials; 
relevant elderly health care, rehabilitation, and nursing home representatives; and caregivers in 
both for-profit and non-profit settings; and (iii) preparation of a report that provides lessons and 
recommendations for the province. The second stage consists of a survey of official ethnic groups 
in the province to analyze differences in health care needs, disease burden, and health-seeking 
behavior among the elderly. This will generate data to guide the recommendations on appropriate 
methods of providing long-term elderly health care services to indigenous communities. The third 
stage involves (i) a desk review of international best practices with respect to elderly health care 
policies and regulations, standards, and practices in Japan, the United Kingdom, the United 
States, and other countries that include for-profit and non-profit sectors; (ii) a desk review of 
available relevant studies conducted in the PRC; and (iii) completion of a report on international 
best practices and recommendations for elderly care and health care integration and provision 
relevant to the province.  
 
10.  Output 2: Policy advice for the development of a framework for elderly health care 
system finalized. Output 2 will establish an operational framework for an effective elderly health 
care system in Yunnan. Building on research and analysis from output 1, output 2 will provide 
policy recommendations for the development of an operational framework for elderly health care 
services  comprising  oversight,  coalition-building,  institutional  arrangements,  regulation,  and 
accountability mechanisms. Options for an elderly health care system will be considered based 
on cost-effectiveness. Consultations will be conducted to ensure feedback and input from for-
profit and non-profit private hospitals and facilities, primary health care providers, rehabilitation 
centers, and nursing homes, including services for rural areas. This output will design the 
monitoring  and  evaluation  system,  including  rule-based  and  output-based  indicators  for 
performance measurement, and ensure continued quality of services as part of the policy and 
operational framework. 
 
11.  Output  3:  Knowledge  and  skills  on  elderly  health  care  service  management 
enhanced. The knowledge and capacity of the relevant agencies of Yunnan Province will be 
enhanced through targeted training and workshops to advance lessons and knowledge generated 
 
10  Government of the PRC, State Council. 2017. Thirteenth Five-Year Plan of System Development for the Aging 
Population. Beijing. 
11  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
by the TA. Output 3 will (i) conduct training and workshops for elderly care and health care 
management staff and stakeholders on the operational framework for the elderly health care 
system;  (ii)  organize  strategic  planning  to  implement  the  required  health  care  system 
improvements; (iii) organize knowledge-sharing workshops to disseminate the findings of the 
elderly health care system assessment; and (iv) develop a publication on the key TA outcomes, 
including the research and development of a strategic policy and operational framework for the 
elderly health care system for Yunnan Province, in English and Chinese. Non-profit entities 
including civil society organizations are important project stakeholders and will be invited to 
participate in training, workshops, and knowledge-sharing activities. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $350,000, of which $250,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, 
communication facilities  for  consultants,  counterpart staff,  administrative  expenses such  as 
printing and dissemination of TA reports and materials, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Health Commission of Yunnan Province will be the 
executing  agency  and the  Yunnan Geriatric  Hospital  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  An 
oversight committee will be organized by the executing agency to provide policy and operational 
direction. ADB will engage both national and international consultants and carry out procurement 
following ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
procurement  staff  instructions.  ADB  will  select,  monitor,  and  evaluate  the  consultants  in 
consultation with the executing and implementing agencies.  
 
15.  The Yunnan Geriatric Hospital will be responsible for providing guidance to the consultants 
engaged under the TA and, in partnership with the Health Commission of Yunnan Province, will 
coordinate with the relevant agencies and institutions involved under the TA. Reports produced 
under the TA will be made available to the public through existing knowledge sharing platforms 
and in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy. Implementation arrangements are 
summarized in the table.

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.12  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Building a Management System for Elderly 
Health Services in Yunnan Province, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.   Elderly health care services assessed   
1.1 Finalize policy environment assessment for elderly health care services, including a narrative report (Q2 
2021)  
1.2 Finalize design and conclude research on health needs, burden of disease, and health seeking behavior 
of elderly in ethnic groups, including a research report (Q4 2021) 
1.3 Develop a report on international best practices and recommendations for elderly care services relevant 
to Yunnan Province (Q1 2022)  
1.4 Complete technical report from output 1 activities (Q2 2022) 
2.   Policy advice for the development a framework for elderly health care system finalized  
2.1 Conduct consultations on the development of an operational framework for elderly health care services 
with private and non-profit health care providers, primary health care providers, rehabilitation centers 
staff, caregivers, and nursing homes (Q3 2021) 
2.2 Finalize recommendations and policy advice for the operational framework for elderly health care 
services with different options based on cost-effectiveness (Q4 2021) 
2.3 Complete the monitoring and evaluation system process and guidelines, including indicators and 
performance measurement (Q4 2021) 
2.4 Complete technical report from output 2 activities (Q1 2022) 
3.   Knowledge and skills on elderly health care service management enhanced 
3.1 Organize workshops and meetings to agree on required operational improvements for elderly health 
care services (Q1 2022) 
3.2 Conduct training on elderly health care system and services (Q1–Q3 2022) 
3.3 Organize dissemination workshops for the results of the research (Q3 2022) 
3.4 Complete publication of TA technical reports (Q4 2022)
